abstract.p: Five Days column; China said its economy expanded by 11 percent in first quarter, putting it on pace to overtake Germany as world's third-largest economy; growth will probably force government to step up efforts to prevent economy from overheating; photo (S)

block.p: BLACKBERRY users' thumbs were idle; private equity investors got a thumbs up from Sallie Mae; and a jury turned thumbs down on Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest.
China said its economy expanded by 11 percent in the first quarter, putting it on a pace to overtake Germany as the world's third-largest economy.
BLACKBERRY users' thumbs were idle; private equity investors got a thumbs up from Sallie Mae; and a jury turned thumbs down on Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest.
China said its economy expanded by 11 percent in the first quarter, putting it on a pace to overtake Germany as the world's third-largest economy.

The growth will probably force Beijing to step up efforts to prevent the economy from overheating. More than a dozen interest rate increases and policy tightening measures over the last three years have been unable to tame the economy.
There is also mounting pressure on China to allow its currency, the yuan, to appreciate more quickly.
One challenge for China is to keep the economy humming ahead of 2008, when Beijing is set to play host to the Summer Olympics.
